articles.headline: How the Secret Service Missed Chances to Halt a Tragedy at a Trump Rally
articles.snippet: Communications gaps, unguarded warehouses and a lack of written instructions opened an opportunity for a gunman at a rally in Butler, Pa., in July.
articles.abstract: Communications gaps, unguarded warehouses and a lack of written instructions opened an opportunity for a gunman at a rally in Butler, Pa., in July.
articles.lead_paragraph: Disorganized communications. Security threats identified but dropped. Vague instructions. Lack of follow-through.
articles.byline: By Eileen Sullivan and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: France’s Budget Problems ‘Very Serious,’ Prime Minister Says
articles.snippet: The French government, which missed a deadline this week to show how it would cut its debt and deficit, is struggling to meet fiscal requirements set by the E.U.
articles.abstract: The French government, which missed a deadline this week to show how it would cut its debt and deficit, is struggling to meet fiscal requirements set by the E.U.
articles.lead_paragraph: France’s new prime minister said Wednesday that the country’s finances were in critical condition, as signs mounted that the government faced an uphill battle to control a ballooning debt and deficit that have become among the highest in Europe.

articles.headline: Trump’s Talk of Prosecution Rattles Election Officials
articles.snippet: The former president has long claimed, despite evidence to the contrary, that elections are corrupt. What if he carries through with threats to prosecute the officials who run them?
articles.abstract: The former president has long claimed, despite evidence to the contrary, that elections are corrupt. What if he carries through with threats to prosecute the officials who run them?
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s escalating calls to investigate and prosecute election officials he sees as “corrupt” are sounding alarms among democracy experts and the local and state workers preparing to run elections and tally millions of votes across the country.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Alexandra Berzon

articles.headline: Second Wave of Blasts Hits Lebanon as Hand-Held Radios Explode
articles.snippet: At least 20 people were killed and more than 450 others wounded, Lebanese officials said, a day after pagers exploded across the country and killed 12 people, in an attack widely attributed to Israel.
articles.abstract: At least 20 people were killed and more than 450 others wounded, Lebanese officials said, a day after pagers exploded across the country and killed 12 people, in an attack widely attributed to Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: A second wave of deadly blasts rocked Lebanon on Wednesday, as hand-held radios that had been covertly turned into explosive devices and carried by Hezbollah members blew up across the country, killing at least 20 people, wounding more than 450 others and shocking the nation.
articles.byline: By Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman, Hwaida Saad and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Chinese Automakers’ Answer to E.U. Tariffs: Build in Europe
articles.snippet: BYD, which leads China’s electric vehicle sector, is constructing a plant in Hungary while its Chinese rivals expand through joint ventures in Europe.
articles.abstract: BYD, which leads China’s electric vehicle sector, is constructing a plant in Hungary while its Chinese rivals expand through joint ventures in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: The leafy city of Szeged, Hungary, boasting wide avenues, a respected university and ornate, pale yellow villas near the country’s border with Serbia, looks more like a relic of the Hapsburg empire than the location of Europe’s automotive future.

articles.headline: America’s Inflation Fight Is Ending, but It’s Leaving a Legacy
articles.snippet: As inflation cools and the Federal Reserve cuts rates, an era of economic upheaval is coming to a close, but not without lingering marks.
articles.abstract: As inflation cools and the Federal Reserve cuts rates, an era of economic upheaval is coming to a close, but not without lingering marks.
articles.lead_paragraph: People with jobs have started showing up at homeless shelters in Atlanta. Families who can’t cover their grocery bills are pushing up demand at a Boston food bank. A dearth of available houses is plaguing Sacramento. Yet reports of recent raises abound, and a partly retired homeowner near Pittsburgh is happy about his savings.

articles.headline: Harris Had Stronger Debate, Polls Find, but the Race Remains Deadlocked
articles.snippet: Kamala Harris holds an edge over Donald J. Trump in the battleground state of Pennsylvania. But new surveys found that the race remains a tossup nationally.
articles.abstract: Kamala Harris holds an edge over Donald J. Trump in the battleground state of Pennsylvania. But new surveys found that the race remains a tossup nationally.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Ruth Igielnik

articles.headline: Backlash Erupts Over Europe’s Anti-Deforestation Law
articles.snippet: Leaders around the world are asking the European Union to delay rules that would require companies to police their global supply chains.
articles.abstract: Leaders around the world are asking the European Union to delay rules that would require companies to police their global supply chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union has been a world leader on climate change, passing groundbreaking legislation to reduce noxious greenhouse gasses. Now the world is pushing back.

articles.headline: On YouTube, Major Brands’ Ads Appear Alongside Racist Falsehoods About Haitian Immigrants
articles.snippet: Large organizations and brands saw their advertising dollars funneled to videos amplifying inflammatory narratives, underscoring how difficult it can be to maintain brand safety online.
articles.abstract: Large organizations and brands saw their advertising dollars funneled to videos amplifying inflammatory narratives, underscoring how difficult it can be to maintain brand safety online.
articles.lead_paragraph: On YouTube, an ad for the car company Mazda appeared before a video that repeated the racist falsehood that Haitian migrants in Ohio were “eating ducks on the side of the road.” An ad for the software giant Adobe showed up alongside another video that claimed “people have had their pets abducted and eaten by people who shouldn’t be in this country.”
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson

articles.headline: Threats Against Haitians Land at the Doorstep of The Haitian Times
articles.snippet: Racist emails. Swatting. Intimidated sources. The Haitian Times has been receiving some of the same threats that it has been covering in Springfield, Ohio.
articles.abstract: Racist emails. Swatting. Intimidated sources. The Haitian Times has been receiving some of the same threats that it has been covering in Springfield, Ohio.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a journalism career that has spanned nearly 40 years, Garry Pierre-Pierre has faced threats, intimidation and open racism by readers of his work.
